Award.AwardTitle: Multi-University Integration of Solid-State Chemistry and Powder X-ray Diffraction into the Undergraduate Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry Division of the Associated Colleges of the Chicago Area (a consortium of 15 small liberal arts colleges), spearheaded by the Chemistry Department at Aurora University, is introducing Powder X-Ray Diffraction (PXDR) instrumentation to undergraduate chemistry students and to K-12 pre-service and in-service teachers. The four goals the project is achieving are: (1) Delivering a two-week, 60-contact hour, 4 credit, research-oriented, solid-state/materials course, through workshops, to the large, broad and diverse undergraduate population served by the consortium, with the course being offered at three distinct times. (2) Delivering summertime research-oriented workshops for pre-service and in-service K-12 teachers that focus on complex instrumentation as applied to synthesis of inorganic materials with potential applications in catalysis, waste remediation, alternative energy, or photonics. (3) Integrating solid-state and materials chemistry coupled with the PXRD instrument across all levels of the undergraduate curriculum at the lead institution. (4) Enhancing research training of upper-division students through undergraduate research experiences built around easy access to a PXRD instrument.

The project is establishing the efficacy of a workshop-style, highly-focused, and time-condensed course in providing significant, research-driven laboratory experiences to students at a time when this is their only intellectual commitment. The project also aims to motivate students to become enthusiastic about chemistry in general, and solid-state chemistry in specific. A long term goal is to increase the number of students who enter graduate programs in solid-state chemistry or who are tapped as highly qualified candidates for the materials industry. The use of the instrument in the support of faculty-mentored research is leading to new experimental findings as well as in the training of next-generation graduate students.

The variety of students eligible for the condensed-format course, from the consortium schools, is ensuring a diverse audience. The coupling of the project to the needs of pre-service and in-service teachers is uniquely presenting hands-on access to sophisticated instrumentation in a deliberate attempt to engender enthusiasm and excitement about the research-based nature of chemistry. The project's courses, workshops, and approach, built around a modestly priced, widely useful instrument can serve as a model for adoptions and adaptations by many other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project team successfully designed and implemented summer workshops for students and teachers with the integration of the x-ray diffraction (PXRD) instrumentation into courses at Aurora University. The goals of the workshops included:  to generate transferable enthusiasm for chemistry, to encourage teachers and students to conduct scientific research and to cultivate teachers’ and students’ appreciation for the scientific process as the systematic, yet uncertain pursuit of new and exciting knowledge.  

The teacher workshop covered the following topics: introduction to single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, characterization of simple ionic solids with the PXRD, understanding crystalline structure of rocks, basic environmental analysis, measurement of sample purity, basics on biomimcry, identifying fine-grained minerals, concepts used in forensics, and understanding results. The student workshops covered the following topics: molecular structure, bonding molecular orbital theory, structure of solids, energetics of ionic bonding, inorganic acids and bases, oxidation, diffraction methods, molecular symmetry, coordination compounds, coordination chemistry, solid-state chemistry, material chemistry, nanomaterials, nanoscience and nanotech.

The following instruments were used to evaluate the goals of the workshops: pre/post test, practical assessment, student portfolios and student workshop assessment. After the workshop, results indicated participants felt more comfortable explaining and using the XRD and overall increased knowledge in applying chemistry.  The teachers stated they will likely integrate workshop knowledge in their high school classrooms along with their enthusiasm. The student participants showed growth in knowledge about the technology; and future learning goals about technology.  All student participants were given time to characterize a round of research samples using the PXRD individually. Student research was presented at several conferences including: the Iota Sigma Pi Chemistry Symposium, the Aurora University Student Symposium, the American Chemical Society National Meeting and the Illinois State Academy of Science Conference.  One of the teacher participants brought a group of twenty-four high school students to the Aurora University campus to do a series of labs on XRD. The teacher developed a pamphlet and lab assignments for this workshop. Students that attended were juniors and seniors from a Forensics class that had been hand selected by the teacher based on interest, work ethic, class performance, and knowledge of the PXRD. This annual opportunity will promote student continued enthusiasm for chemistry. There were also opportunities for teachers and faculty to meet professionals in the industry and discuss uses of the instrument. The professionals that came to speak to the workshop included individuals from Cabot Microelectronics, Illinois State Forensics Lab and Rigaku. Several Cabot employees have been frequently using the PXRD for their research.  

Students overwhelmingly expressed a preference for this type of experiential, condensed learning experience, as compared to traditional coursework where laboratory and lecture are separated and experiments are not of a research type. We expect that faculty will take notice of this curricular model and perhaps incorporate into their own institutions' undergraduate curricula.
